metatags.og:title: An Overview of Maine Privacy Law
metatags.og:description: Introduction Verrill’s Data Protection and Privacy attorneys have created this resource as a comprehensive overview of key privacy laws in Maine. This article reflects the laws as of mid-2024 and may be updated periodically. Readers should be aware that it does not aim to cover every law that is typically considered a “privacy” law. We hope it serves as a valuable summary of the topics addressed, and we welcome any feedback or questions at any time. Contact Adam Nyhan at anyhan@verrill-law.com. Adam Nyhan is a Partner in Verrill’s Portland, Maine office. He has represented technology companies in privacy, intellectual property, advertising, and corporate matters since 2004. Privacy Under the Maine State Constitution The Constitution of the State of Maine (“Maine Constitution”) does not establish a general privacy right. Section 5 of the Maine Constitution, which generally mirrors the Fourth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States (“U.S. Constitution”), provides that “[t]he people

metatags.og:title: Maine Legislature Fails to Enact Privacy Law
metatags.og:description: The Maine Data Privacy and Protection Act, LD1977, passed the Maine House of Representatives yesterday before being defeated in the Senate on a 15-18 vote.
